Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. A. Alan Pinkerton and Dr. Elizabeth Zhurova from the University of Toledo, will quantitatively characterize important weak interactions between atoms or molecules in the solid state using advanced, high resolution, X-ray crystallographic techniques. The electron density distribution will be determined from the intensities of the X-rays scattered from single crystals, and quantified by fitting the parameters of an atom-centered multipole expansion to the observed data. A range of intra- and inter-molecular interactions that have been previously identified from structural data, many with "non-bonded" distances significantly below the sum of the Van der Waals radii, will be studied. Currently potential interactions between 20 different atom pairs have been identified for 20 different molecular solids. Information from this study will provide new insight into a wide spectrum of scientific areas such as materials design/crystal engineering and biological ligand-receptor binding/cell signaling.

Properties of all materials are intimately related to the distribution of electrons between the atoms and molecules. For example, diamond and graphite are composed entirely of carbon atoms, but have vastly different properties, diamond being very hard, and graphite being a soft lubricant. This is easily understood as the distribution of electrons in diamond leads to strong covalent bonds in three dimensions, whereas graphite is strongly bonded in two dimensions, and weakly bonded in the third. The importance of strong chemical bonds has been recognized by generations of chemists, and their characterization by theory and experiment is the material for text books. The importance of weak interactions, with the exception of hydrogen bonds, has not been systematically studied using X-ray diffraction techniques until now, and represents a new investigative direction in chemistry. This pursuit will allow graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to acquire specialized training in cryogenics, and in high resolution X-ray crystallography. The new methods for cryogenic data collection and analysis, followed by workshops to train others, will push the limits of what is experimentally obtainable. This project will also be integrated into an outreach program to introduce high school students to the science of crystallography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical substances may exist as solids, liquids or gases. Some solid materials are hard, some soft; some are brittle and some flexible. A good example of this variation in properties is provided by carbon. This element commonly occurs as diamond, which is extremely hard, or graphite which is much softer. These different properties are determined by the forces that exist between atoms or molecules. In the case of diamond, there are strong chemical bonds in three dimensions, whereas the carbon atoms in graphite are strongly bonded in two dimensions, and weakly bound in the third. This difference in bonding is responsible for the vastly different physical properties of diamond and graphite, despite both being composed of elemental carbon.

There is much interest in designing new materials, either for technological applications or as pharmaceuticals. To determine how to achieve desired characteristics in new materials, it is essential to understand the origin and magnitude of the forces holding atoms or molecules together. The strong bonds (covalent bonds) that hold the atoms together in diamond, or indeed in all molecular species, are well understood, and are described in text books. Of the weaker interactions, the so called “hydrogen bond”, an order of magnitude weaker than covalent bonds, is fairly well characterized. The hydrogen bond is responsible for holding water (H2O) molecules together in the liquid or in ice. However, it does not occur in hydrogen sulfide (H­­­2S), which for this reason is a gas. The known strength and directionality of hydrogen bonds is currently being used to design new materials. This is the discipline of crystal engineering. However, less is known about other weak bonds. We have set out to identify and characterize other such bonds, frequently about an order of magnitude weaker than hydrogen bonds, to provide additional tools for developing new materials.

In order to study these bonds, we irradiate crystalline materials with X-rays at very low temperature (20 K = -253°C = -423°F). We are then able to find the positions of the atoms and map the distribution of the electrons associated with them, creating a three dimensional image of the internal structure of a crystal. From this information, we can identify pairs of atoms that interact with each other, and measure the strength of the interaction. In addition to the more well-known hydrogen bonds, we have identified and characterized weak interactions between the following pairs of atoms as they exist in a wide spectrum of compounds (for example explosives, hormones, pesticides, ferroelectrics): CH---O, C---C, C---O, O---O, O---N, N---N, H---H.
